content: The "Teachers and First Responders Back to Work Act of 2012" authorizes grants to States for preventing teacher layoffs and creating jobs in public education for the 2012-2014 school years. The "Teachers and First Responders Back to Work Act of 2012" authorizes grants to States for preventing teacher layoffs and creating jobs in public education for the 2012-2014 school years. From the appropriated amount, the Secretary reserves funds to provide assistance to outlying areas and the Secretary of the Interior for activities consistent with the title. The Secretary reserves funds for assistance to the Bureau of Indian Education schools and for administration and oversight of the program. Award amounts for each State are determined based on a percentage of remaining funds after reservations are made. The Secretary determines award amounts for each State based on population ratios of individuals aged 5 through 17. The Secretary allocates funds to States based on population ratios of individuals aged 5 through 17. If a State does not receive a grant, the Secretary reallocates the funds to other States using a specific formula based on population ratios. SEC. 103. STATE APPLICATION. State chief executives must submit an application to the Secretary within 30 days of this Act's enactment to request a grant. The application must include specific information and an assurance that the State will maintain support for education at or above the level of fiscal year 2011 for fiscal years 2012 and 2013. The State chief executives must submit an application to the Secretary within 30 days of the Act's enactment to request a grant. The application must include specific information and an assurance that the State will maintain support for education at or above the level of fiscal year 2011 for fiscal years 2012 and 2013. The State must either maintain support for education at the same level as fiscal year 2011 or at a percentage of total expenditures equal to or greater than that provided in fiscal year 2011. The State chief executives must submit an application within 30 days of the Act's enactment to request a grant. The application must include an assurance that the State will maintain support for education at or above the level of fiscal year 2011 for fiscal years 2012 and 2013. The Secretary may waive the assurance requirement for a State if deemed equitable. The Secretary may waive the assurance requirement for a State if exceptional circumstances, such as a natural disaster, or a significant decline in the State's financial resources, are determined by the Secretary to be equitable. SEC. 104. STATE GRANTS. State grants under this title require each State to reserve a portion of the funds for State-funded early learning programs and administrative costs. The remaining grant funds are to be used for awards to local educational agencies to support early childhood, elementary, and secondary public education. The remaining grant funds under this title are to be used for awards to local educational agencies for early childhood, elementary, and secondary public education support. States must distribute these funds through subgrants based on enrollment ratios. The State must allocate grant funds to local educational agencies based on enrollment ratios, with 60 percent allocated proportionally and 40 percent based on funds received under part A of title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act. The State must allocate remaining grant funds to local educational agencies based on enrollment ratios, with subgrants made available within 100 days of receiving the grant. A State receiving a grant under this Act must make subgrants available to local educational agencies within 100 days. The grant funds cannot be used to establish or supplement a rainy-day fund, reduce debt obligations, or supplant State funds. The State receiving a grant under this Act cannot use the funds to establish, restore, or supplement a rainy-day fund, reduce or retire debt obligations, or supplant State funds for the same purpose. SEC. 105 of the Act specifies that local educational agencies must use subgrant funds for employee-related expenses to provide educational services. SEC. 106 focuses on early learning programs. SEC. 106 of the Act outlines that State-funded early learning programs must use funds for retaining, recalling, or hiring early childhood educators. Funds must be obligated by September 30, 2014. SEC. 107 requires States receiving grants to submit reports on fund usage and job support by September 30 of 2013 and 2014. SEC. 108 defines key terms such as "local educational agency", "outlying area", "State educational agency", and "State-funded early learning program". The term "State" includes the 50 States, the District of Columbia, and the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2012 and 2013 totaling $30 billion for a grant program to support law enforcement officers and firefighters. The Secretary of Homeland Security is authorized to make competitive grants to hire, rehire, and retain firefighters and maintain resources for fire departments. The Secretary may waive certain requirements in the Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974. Additional funds are authorized for these grants. Authorization of $1,000,000,000 for grants under the Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 for fiscal years 2012 and 2013, with a reservation of $2,000,000 for administrative costs. SEC. 203. LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICER GRANT PROGRAM. The Attorney General will provide competitive grants to hire, rehire, and retain law enforcement officers under the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968. These grants are not subject to certain sections of the Act. Additional funds are authorized for these grants. The Attorney General will provide competitive grants under the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 to hire, rehire, and retain law enforcement officers. $4,000,000,000 is authorized to be appropriated for fiscal years 2012 and 2013, with a portion reserved for administrative costs.
